results.title: city diary_04
results.brief_description: An anonymous digital dairy created by a young person as part of a day long workshop run by ACMI. Each diary is scripted and a voiceover recorded by the individual young person. Some diaries use photographs brought in by the participant, but the primary visual content is often black and white, ‘stock’ footage of a poetic nature. At no point should the creator or school be positively identified when screening this work.

results.title: History of a day
results.brief_description:
The time lapse photography in History of a Day offers an exhilarating view of a ‘day’ unfolding before our eyes in just four minutes. The five screens of the installation surround the viewer with multiple sunrises, sunsets and lightning storms - a global dance of energy and light not available to us from our usual fixed and single perspective.

History of a Day shows us the Earth as a spinning ball of elements, driven by the laws of gravity and physics, producing, in the words of the artists, ‘a cosmic special effects theatre in continuous production, simultaneously all over the earth.’

Cinematographer Simon Carroll has been photographing time-lapse sequences for twenty years, and has amassed a large archive of material from which History of a Day was constructed. His work has been used in many films, including The Matrix (1999). Composer Martin Friedel has written music for film, theatre, opera and the concert hall, using both traditional and new media forms. He is currently a Creative Fellow at the State Library of Victoria.

(FT 30.03.05)

results.title: Funny business
results.creator_credit: David Hinton, Sarah Williams and Tiger Television
results.brief_description: Rowan Atkinson knows his rubber face and gangly limbs are his tools of trade. The exaggerated gestures, tortured twitch of an eyebrow or deadpan expression guaranteed the phenomenal success of “Not the Nine O’Clock News”, “Black Adder” and “Mr. Bean”. There is however an art to being funny, and as mime artist Kevin Bartholomew (dressed in a lime green skin-tight body suit) the amazing rubber-faced one shows us, along with fellow comedy masters including John Cleese and Peter Sellers, that there is comedy potential in every part of the human anatomy.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Hinton, Sarah Williams and Tiger Television

results.title: [Darcy Prendergast's Light Pen Animation]
results.brief_description: Animator Darcy Prendergast was commissioned by ACMI to make some light-hearted works – representing film, TV and games – for display on screens throughout the ACMI building. Using his lightpen technique and combining computer animated movement with real-life locations, the films are a ‘hat-tip’ to the internationally popular feature films and characters of the Australian film industry.

results.title: Custom MAME arcade machine
results.brief_description: One way to preserve videogames is emulation, which recreates retro hardware and software on modern machines. MAME (Multiple Arcade Machine Emulator) is one of the most important emulation tools.
results.description:
It’s not that easy to keep videogames running. Technology evolves at a rapid pace, including software and hardware, making some of the most iconic games from the past unplayable on today’s technology. Not to mention all the parts and programs used in videogames that are long obsolete and no longer supported. In the past fifty years, countless games have been lost.

But it’s not all bad. One of the most important tools to preserve videogames is emulation, which recreates the hardware and software needed to run games on modern machines.

MAME, or Multiple Arcade Machine Emulator, is one of the most well-known and important emulation tools. It recreates the inner workings of thousands of arcade machines, letting players in the present a chance to play the best games of the past.
description_for_label:

But it’s not all bad. One of the most important tools to preserve videogames is emulation, which recreates the hardware and software needed to run games on modern machines.

MAME, or Multiple Arcade Machine Emulator, is one of the most well-known and important emulation tools. It recreates the inner workings of thousands of arcade machines, letting players in the present a chance to play the best games of the past.

results.title: Tripoli Melbourne & Me!
results.creator_credit: Dania Dabliz, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Dania Dabliz’s life in Tripoli was full of fun, friends and parties. When she migrated to Melbourne she wondered if she would find the same things again?

results.title: Dad's tools
results.creator_credit: Fred Atwell, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: There is a lot to do after a bushfire but Fred Atwell wants more than anything to find his dad’s cherished homemade tools. This Digital Storytelling project was created in partnership with Latrobe City and Arts Victoria.
